panels.description: Resource pressure via PSI
panels.title: Pressure

panels.description: Overall CPU busy percentage (averaged across all cores)
panels.title: CPU Busy

panels.description: System load  over all CPU cores together
panels.title: Sys Load

panels.description: Real RAM usage excluding cache and reclaimable memory
panels.title: RAM Used

panels.description: Percentage of swap space currently used by the system
panels.title: SWAP Used

panels.description: Used Root FS
panels.title: Root FS Used

panels.description: CPU time spent busy vs idle, split by activity type
panels.title: CPU Basic

panels.description: RAM and swap usage overview, including caches
panels.title: Memory Basic

panels.description: Per-interface network traffic (receive and transmit) in bits per second
panels.title: Network Traffic Basic

panels.description: Percentage of filesystem space used for each mounted device

targets.expr: ((node_filesystem_size_bytes{instance="$node", job="$job", device!~"rootfs"} - node_filesystem_avail_bytes{instance="$node", job="$job", device!~"rootfs"}) / node_filesystem_size_bytes{instance="$node", job="$job", device!~"rootfs"}) * 100

panels.title: Disk Space Used Basic

panels.description: CPU time usage split by state, normalized across all CPU cores

matcher.options: Idle - Waiting for something to happen
Iowait - Waiting for I/O to complete
Nice - Niced processes executing in user mode
Steal - Time spent in other operating systems when running in a virtualized environment
System - Processes executing in kernel mode
User - Normal processes executing in user mode

targets.legendFormat: System - Processes executing in kernel mode
User - Normal processes executing in user mode
Nice - Niced processes executing in user mode
Iowait - Waiting for I/O to complete
Steal - Time spent in other operating systems when running in a virtualized environment
Idle - Waiting for something to happen

targets.expr: sum by(instance) (irate(node_cpu_guest_seconds_total{instance="$node",job="$job"}[$__rate_interval])) / on(instance) group_left sum by (instance)((irate(node_cpu_seconds_total{instance="$node",job="$job"}[$__rate_interval]))) > 0

panels.title: CPU

panels.description: Breakdown of physical memory and swap usage. Hardware-detected memory errors are also displayed

matcher.options: Hardware Corrupted - Amount of RAM that the kernel identified as corrupted / not working

targets.legendFormat: Apps - Memory used by user-space applications
PageTables - Memory used to map between virtual and physical memory addresses
SwapCache - Memory that keeps track of pages that have been fetched from swap but not yet been modified
Slab - Memory used by the kernel to cache data structures for its own use (caches like inode, dentry, etc)
Cache - Parked file data (file content) cache
Hardware Corrupted - Amount of RAM that the kernel identified as corrupted / not working

panels.title: Memory

panels.description: Incoming and outgoing network traffic per interface
panels.title: Network Traffic

panels.description: Network interface utilization as a percentage of its maximum capacity
panels.title: Network Saturation

panels.description: Disk I/O operations per second for each device
panels.title: Disk IOps

panels.description: Disk I/O throughput per device
panels.title: Disk Throughput

panels.description: Amount of available disk space per mounted filesystem, excluding rootfs. Based on block availability to non-root users
panels.title: Filesystem Space Available

panels.description: Disk usage (used = total - available) per mountpoint
panels.title: Filesystem Used

panels.description: Percentage of time the disk was actively processing I/O operations
panels.title: Disk I/O Utilization

panels.description:
How often tasks experience CPU, memory, or I/O delays. “Some” indicates partial slowdown; “Full” indicates all tasks are stalled. Based on Linux PSI metrics:
https://docs.kernel.org/accounting/psi.html
panels.title: Pressure Stall Information

panels.description: Displays committed memory usage versus the system's commit limit. Exceeding the limit is allowed under Linux overcommit policies but may increase OOM risks under high load

targets.legendFormat: Committed_AS – Memory promised to processes (not necessarily used)

panels.title: Memory Committed

panels.description: Memory currently dirty (modified but not yet written to disk), being actively written back, or held by writeback buffers. High dirty or writeback memory may indicate disk I/O pressure or delayed flushing

targets.legendFormat: Writeback – Memory currently being flushed to disk
Dirty – Memory marked dirty (pending write to disk)
NFS Unstable – Pages sent to NFS server, awaiting storage commit

panels.title: Memory Writeback and Dirty

panels.description: Kernel slab memory usage, separated into reclaimable and non-reclaimable categories. Reclaimable memory can be freed under memory pressure (e.g., caches), while unreclaimable memory is locked by the kernel for core functions

targets.legendFormat: SReclaimable – Potentially reclaimable slab memory (e.g., inode cache)

panels.title: Memory Slab

panels.description: Memory used for mapped files (such as libraries) and shared memory (shmem and tmpfs), including variants backed by huge pages

targets.legendFormat: Mapped – Memory mapped from files (e.g., libraries, mmap)
Shmem – Shared memory used by processes and tmpfs
ShmemHugePages – Shared memory (shmem/tmpfs) allocated with HugePages
PMD Mapped – Shmem/tmpfs backed by Transparent HugePages (PMD)

panels.title: Memory Shared and Mapped

panels.description: Proportion of memory pages in the kernel's active and inactive LRU lists relative to total RAM. Active pages have been recently used, while inactive pages are less recently accessed but still resident in memory

targets.legendFormat: Inactive – Less recently used memory, more likely to be reclaimed
Active – Recently used memory, retained unless under pressure

panels.title: Memory LRU Active / Inactive (%)

panels.description: Breakdown of memory pages in the kernel's active and inactive LRU lists, separated by anonymous (heap, tmpfs) and file-backed (caches, mmap) pages.

targets.legendFormat: Inactive_file - File-backed memory on inactive LRU list
Inactive_anon – Anonymous memory on inactive LRU (incl. tmpfs & swap cache)
Active_file - File-backed memory on active LRU list
Active_anon – Anonymous memory on active LRU (incl. tmpfs & swap cache)

panels.title: Memory LRU Active / Inactive Detail

panels.description: Tracks kernel memory used for CPU-local structures, per-thread stacks, and bounce buffers used for I/O on DMA-limited devices. These areas are typically small but critical for low-level operations

targets.legendFormat: PerCPU – Dynamically allocated per-CPU memory (used by kernel modules)
Bounce Memory – I/O buffer for DMA-limited devices

panels.title: Memory Kernel / CPU / IO

panels.description: Usage of the kernel's vmalloc area, which provides virtual memory allocations for kernel modules and drivers. Includes total, used, and largest free block sizes

targets.legendFormat: Vmalloc Free Chunk – Largest available block in vmalloc area
Vmalloc Total – Total size of the vmalloc memory area
Vmalloc Used – Portion of vmalloc area currently in use

panels.title: Memory Vmalloc

panels.description: Memory used by anonymous pages (not backed by files), including standard and huge page allocations. Includes heap, stack, and memory-mapped anonymous regions
panels.title: Memory Anonymous

panels.description: Memory that is locked in RAM and cannot be swapped out. Includes both kernel-unevictable memory and user-level memory locked with mlock()

matcher.options: Hardware Corrupted - Amount of RAM that the kernel identified as corrupted / not working

panels.title: Memory Unevictable and MLocked

panels.description: How much memory is directly mapped in the kernel using different page sizes (4K, 2M, 1G). Helps monitor large page utilization in the direct map region
panels.title: Memory DirectMap

panels.description: Displays HugePages memory usage in bytes, including allocated, free, reserved, and surplus memory. All values are calculated based on the number of huge pages multiplied by their configured size
panels.title: Memory HugePages

panels.description: Rate of memory pages being read from or written to disk (page-in and page-out operations). High page-out may indicate memory pressure or swapping activity
panels.title: Memory Pages In / Out

panels.description: Rate at which memory pages are being swapped in from or out to disk. High swap-out activity may indicate memory pressure
panels.title: Memory Pages Swap In / Out

panels.description: Rate of memory page faults, split into total, major (disk-backed), and derived minor (non-disk) faults. High major fault rates may indicate memory pressure or insufficient RAM

matcher.options: Pgfault - Page major and minor fault ops

targets.legendFormat: Pgfault - Page major and minor fault ops

panels.title: Memory Page Faults

panels.description: Rate of Out-of-Memory (OOM) kill events. A non-zero value indicates the kernel has terminated one or more processes due to memory exhaustion
panels.title: OOM Killer

panels.description: Tracks the system clock's estimated and maximum error, as well as its offset from the reference clock (e.g., via NTP). Useful for detecting synchronization drift
panels.title: Time Synchronized Drift

panels.description: NTP phase-locked loop (PLL) time constant used by the kernel to control time adjustments. Lower values mean faster correction but less stability
panels.title: Time PLL Adjust

panels.description: Shows whether the system clock is synchronized to a reliable time source, and the current frequency correction ratio applied by the kernel to maintain synchronization
panels.title: Time Sync Status

panels.description: Displays the number of network packets received and transmitted per interface, including error and drop counts
panels.title: Network Packets

panels.description: Rate of network packet errors and drops per interface. High error rates may indicate hardware issues or network congestion
panels.title: Network Errors and Dropped Packets

panels.description: Rate of network multicast packets received per interface. Useful for monitoring multicast traffic patterns
panels.title: Network Multicast

panels.description: Rate of network FIFO (First In, First Out) buffer errors and collisions per interface. High values may indicate network congestion or hardware issues
panels.title: Network FIFO and Collisions

panels.description: Rate of network carrier and frame errors per interface. Carrier errors indicate physical layer issues, while frame errors suggest data corruption
panels.title: Network Carrier and Frame

panels.description: Rate of network compressed packets received and transmitted per interface. Useful for monitoring compression efficiency
panels.title: Network Compressed

panels.description: Maximum transmission unit (MTU) size for each network interface. Shows the largest packet size that can be transmitted without fragmentation
panels.title: Network MTU

panels.description: Network interface speed in bits per second. Shows the configured link speed for each interface
panels.title: Network Speed

panels.description: Average time spent per disk I/O operation (read and write) in milliseconds. High latency may indicate disk performance issues
panels.title: Disk Average Wait Time

panels.description: Average size of disk I/O operations (read and write) in bytes. Helps identify I/O patterns and efficiency
panels.title: Disk Average Request Size

panels.description: Average number of I/O operations in the disk queue. High queue depth may indicate disk saturation or slow storage
panels.title: Disk Average Queue Size (aqu-sz)

panels.description: Rate of disk operations that were merged before being sent to the device. High merge rates indicate efficient I/O coalescing
panels.title: Disk Merged Operations

panels.description: Rate of discarded sectors per disk device. Discard operations are used by SSDs for TRIM commands to optimize performance
panels.title: Disk Discarded Sectors

panels.description: Rate of flush operations per disk device. Flush operations ensure data is written to persistent storage
panels.title: Disk Flush Requests

panels.description: Number of inodes (file system objects) used and available per mounted filesystem. Running out of inodes can prevent file creation even with available disk space
panels.title: Filesystem Inodes

panels.description: Percentage of inodes used per mounted filesystem. High inode usage can prevent file creation
panels.title: Filesystem Inodes Used %

panels.description: Shows whether each filesystem is mounted read-only (1) or read-write (0). Read-only filesystems cannot be modified
panels.title: Filesystem Read Only

panels.description: Shows the device major and minor numbers for each filesystem. Useful for identifying the underlying block devices
panels.title: Filesystem Device Error
